word.entryDescription: a situation in which your computer, tablet, etc is connected to the Internet
word.entryExample: James complained that he couldn't get a good internet connection.

word.entryDescription: a job training for college or university students, high school students, or post-graduate adults; may be paid or unpaid and is usually temporary
word.entryExample: Have you considered doing an internship at the local newspaper?

word.entryDescription: to explain the meaning of something
word.entryExample: We interpret body language in order to understand each other.

word.entryDescription: somebody who translates what somebody is saying into another language
word.entryExample: Communicating with customers in their own language, so you don't have to wait for interpreters to translate in meetings, saves such a lot of time on a business trip.

word.entryDescription: to stop someone in the middle of what they are doing or saying by suddenly doing or saying something
word.entryExample: Jake interrupts Sarah to make an important call.

word.entryDescription: sports training which consists of activities requiring different speeds or amounts of effort
word.entryExample: Interval training involves alternating between fast and slow exercise such as cycling slowly, then cycling as fast as you can, then cycling slowly again.

word.entryDescription: to ask someone questions at a formal meeting to find out if they are suitable for a job, etc
word.entryExample: Jake is interviewing Sarah.

word.entryDescription: not willing to accept any opinions, beliefs, etc that are different from your own; not tolerant
word.entryExample: Mrs Sharp is intolerant of anyone who is slower than her.

word.entryDescription: the way your voice goes up and down when you speak, which affects the meaning of what is being said
word.entryExample: Philip uses rising intonation here to show he is excited.

word.entryDescription: to spend money on something to make it better
word.entryExample: They invested all their money in their son's business.

word.entryDescription: to examine a crime, a problem, an accident, etc in order to find out the truth
word.entryExample: Detectives investigated, but found no evidence.

word.entryDescription: the act of examining a crime, a problem, an accident, etc in order to find out the truth
word.entryExample: The case can be solved and the criminal arrested and convicted with very little investigation.

word.entryDescription: a spoken or written request for somebody to come and do something
word.entryExample: I'm making invitations for Kim's party.

word.entryDescription: to ask someone to come to your home or an event
word.entryExample: Do you think I should invite Kate to the party tonight?

word.entryDescription: to include something
word.entryExample: What does the job involve?

word.entryDescription: a household task which involves making clothes smooth with an iron
word.entryExample: Blocking is the process of fixing the shape of the hat, usually done by ironing.

word.entryDescription: of or from Italy
word.entryExample: Filo is an Italian restaurant right in the heart of downtown Buenos Aires.

word.entryDescription: (for a part of the skin) to have an uncomfortable feeling that you feel like rubbing with your nails
word.entryExample: If a bee stings me, I get a rash and I start to itch.

word.entryDescription: you say this when you see rain (=water from clouds in the sky)
word.entryExample: Oh dear, it's raining - what can we do?

word.entryDescription: a short coat
word.entryExample: Dad is wearing his green jacket.

word.entryDescription: a soft food made from cooked fruit and sugar
word.entryExample: I just need some bread and some jam.

word.entryDescription: a type of modern music with an unusual beat in which the musicians often like experimenting
word.entryExample: I'm not a big fan of jazz.

word.entryDescription: feeling angry and unhappy when someone close to you receives attention from someone else, or when someone has something you desire
word.entryExample: I feel a little jealous because Emma and Harry hung out with each other.

word.entryDescription: a feeling of anger and unhappiness when someone close to you receives attention from someone else, or when someone has something you desire
word.entryExample: Kate will have to deal with her jealousy if she wants to be friends with Emma again.

word.entryDescription: trousers made from denim
word.entryExample: Do you want to wear these jeans today?

word.entryDescription: something you do to earn money
word.entryExample: I got my first summer job as a shop assistant.

word.entryDescription: a text that employers place in a newspaper describing a job which is open for applications
word.entryExample: I saw the job advertisement on the Internet.

word.entryDescription: a formal request for a job, usually made in writing
word.entryExample: The careers adviser gave me lots of help with my job application.

word.entryDescription: the activity of looking for a job
word.entryExample: How’s the job hunt going?

word.entryDescription: exercise in which you run slowly for a long time
word.entryExample: I prefer swimming to jogging.

word.entryDescription: to become a member of a club
word.entryExample: At Fun Land, you can join a club.

word.entryDescription: something which you do or say to make people laugh
word.entryExample: She can tell a joke in Spanish.

word.entryDescription: somebody who writes for a newspaper or magazine, or broadcasts news
word.entryExample: Mum's a journalist and she loves it, particularly when she goes to other countries.

word.entryDescription: the act of moving from one place to another, often over distance
word.entryExample: Sarah wants to start another journey.

word.entryDescription: a person who steals a car and drives around in it for fun
word.entryExample: Electronic speed control could signal the end of getaway cars and joyriders.

word.entryDescription: a person who decides who has won a competition
word.entryExample: Rachel and Lucy didn't enjoy playing their guitars and singing for the judges.

word.entryDescription: to form an opinion about somebody / something based on the knowledge you have about them
word.entryExample: She feels she has been judged unfairly.

word.entryDescription: the liquid that comes from fruit and vegetables
word.entryExample: I bought a big carton of apple juice

word.entryDescription: to use your legs to push up off or away from a surface
word.entryExample: I always laugh and jump when I'm happy.

word.entryDescription: a warm piece of clothing you wear on the top half of your body, often made of wool
word.entryExample: I wear a green jumper to school.

word.entryDescription: an activity in which you jump
word.entryExample: Stop jumping on your bed!

word.entryDescription: an area where there are a lot of trees in a hot country
word.entryExample: Parrots live in the jungle.

word.entryDescription: food which is often quick and easy to prepare and eat, but is unhealthy
word.entryExample: There's no place for junk food in a healthy diet.

word.entryDescription: a member of a jury
word.entryExample: Athens' money paid jurors and chancellors, built a navy and maintained the army.

word.entryDescription: an Australian animal which moves by jumping on its strong back legs and carries its young in a pocket on its stomach
word.entryExample: Kangaroos come from Australia.

word.entryDescription: a closed canoe with a hole in the top for someone to sit in, which you control with a long pole which is wide at both ends
word.entryExample: There's a kayak race on the river today.

word.entryDescription: very interested in something, or wanting something very much
word.entryExample: Why is Steve so keen to explore space?

word.entryDescription: to do physical exercises, in order to improve your strength and to stay healthy
word.entryExample: I know I should try to keep fit, but I have all sorts of allergies that make sports and exercise quite difficult.

word.entryDescription: to continue being physically strong and well
word.entryExample: What do you do to keep healthy?

word.entryDescription: to prevent something from moving
word.entryExample: Elastic and string are simple accessories keeping clothes in place.
